You're not overthinking this at all - you've identified a real ethical tension that goes to the heart of what your account represents and your relationship with your followers.

The fact that you built your following on authenticity isn't just a marketing strategy - it's essentially a promise you've made to your audience. When people follow lifestyle accounts, they're often looking for genuine recommendations from someone whose judgment they trust. If you start promoting products you don't believe in, you're potentially exploiting that trust for financial gain.

Your friends who say "everyone knows these are ads" are partially right about disclosure, but I think they're missing something important. - Only accept partnerships for products you're genuinely willing to try and can honestly evaluate
- Be transparent about your experience level with products ("I'm new to this brand but excited to test it")
- Develop clear criteria for what you will and won't promote, regardless of payment
- Consider whether the financial pressure is pushing you toward compromises you'll regret later

The student loan pressure is real and valid, but ask yourself: would damaging the trust you've built with your audience ultimately hurt your long-term earning potential more than the short-term financial relief would help?

What feels right to you when you imagine looking back on this decision in a few years?

Given how thoughtfully you're approaching this, I suspect you'd land on the "better" side - but ultimately, you have to decide what level of complicity you can live with.

What feels like the right balance to you between engaging with the system and maintaining your values?
